answers.answer: Sometimes having low vitamin D has a knock-on effect to the thyroid - a lot of the symptoms you describe there could be attributed to an under-active thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) and if he already has diabetes it's a possibility.Make sure they test the Free T4 and Free T3 levels as well as the TSH.Good luck :)

question: My husband has been complaining of a feeling in his chest area of food not wanting to go down all the way to the stomach.  He used to get the dry heaves and once in a while actually throw up.  That went away for a while and now he is complaining about it again.  He has had ultra-sounds, CT-scans, endoscopy, 24-hour EEG and blood tests.  No one can come up with a reason or a cure.  For about the last month he has been extremely sore all over his body.  We went for about a two block walk and he was so sore after and the next day that he could hardly move.  His eating habits have changed and he is having trouble sleeping.  He is a diabetic and we are just getting his blood sugar down below 150 with medicine and diet.  He is depressed and never feels like doing anything.  He doesn't associate with anyone but me so he doesn't have a lot of interests.  He goes to the doctor regularly.  He is scheduled to have a blood test in June.  Among many other things that will be tested, she ordered a Vitamin D level test.  I have been reading a lot about Vitamin D deficiencies and am thinking that could be his problem.  Has anyone else had the feeling in the chest area he complains about?
title: Vitamin D Deficiency
